Hoosiers rout Savannah St., U of L up next

Zach Osterman, Indianapolis Star 7:50 a.m. EST December 7, 2014

IU coach Tom Crean recaps the Hoosiers' 95-49 win over Savannah State, which moved his team to 7-1 on the season.

Indiana guard Yogi Ferrell, right, tries to steal the ball away from Savannah State's Terel Hall (22) during a NCAA men's basketball game on Saturday, Dec. 6, 2014, at Assembly Hall in Bloomington.(Photo: James Brosher/For The Star)

CONNECT 5 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

BLOOMINGTON

– Watching Purdue and Michigan suffer surprise home upsets Saturday wasn't a lesson for Indiana, but rather a refresher course.

The Hoosiers (7-1) needed no reminders Saturday, in a 95-49 win, of the dangers of overlooking a weak opponent, after their upset loss at home earlier this season to Eastern Washington. Now they are running out of weak opponents.

Indiana defeated a vastly overmatched Savannah State (3-6) team thanks to 10 made 3-pointers, 15 forced turnovers, a plus-18 advantage rebounding the ball and a host of other stats explaining just how much better the Hoosiers are.

But starting Tuesday night in New York City, this team begins a series of sterner tests, ones that will examine Indiana's NCAA tournament credentials much more thoroughly.

The cupcakes are not gone, but with five non-conference games remaining, Indiana still has No. 5 Louisville, No. 23 Butler and Georgetown upcoming. The Hoosiers' first eight games were at fan-friendly Assembly Hall; they play the Cardinals, Bulldogs and Hoyas on neutral courts.

In the next three weeks, we'll learn what we need to about this group.

"I've seen enough to know from last year and years past, and even a little bit this year, that their pressure defense is as good as anybody's in the country," IU coach Tom Crean said of the undefeated Cardinals.

Savannah State might have offered a limited preview, forcing Indiana to deal with full-court pressure through much of Saturday's game.

Louisville prefers a full-court press, and it's dangerous. The Cardinals are allowing opponents fewer than 50 points per game through seven, and they are second nationally in adjusted defensive efficiency, according to KenPom.com.

Indiana had problems when the Tigers first broke out their press but adjusted to it superbly, finishing with 21 assists to 14 turnovers, and 17 fast-break points.

"We just can't hold the ball," said junior point guard Yogi Ferrell, who finished with a team-high seven assists, along with 18 points. "We've got to attack the press."

These compartmentalized lessons are the real value of paycheck games.

Savannah State was never a match for Indiana, but the Tigers brought something to the game the Hoosiers will soon see again.

If you want your team to be ready for Louisville's press, you'd better start with one that's not quite so overwhelming. Indiana goes to New York with the details and requirements of its press offense fresh. You give a young group something that looks like Pitt before it sees the genuine article, and maybe you get the kind of complete performance IU turned in against the Panthers last week.

"We've put a good week together, back-to-back games," Crean said.

That's what you hope IU takes away from a pedestrian blowout.

It's what Crean will hope his team has absorbed enough of through the first quarter of this season, because Big Ten play is now less than four weeks away, and Indiana has much tougher teams to beat between now and then.

The Hoosiers needed no reminder of how to stumble into an unexpected upset Saturday, but that's not going to be a chief concern Tuesday. It's time for them to prove themselves.

Follow Star reporter Zach Osterman on Twitter: @ZachOsterman.

INDIANA 95, SAVANNAH ST. 49

SAVANNAH ST. (3-6)

Muhammad 5-9 3-6 13, Jenkins 4-8 2-2 11, Pinkett 0-3 0-2 0, Francis 0-3 0-0 0, Hall 0-3 0-1 0, Norman 0-2 0-0 0, Fenner 2-10 3-4 7, Carter 0-0 0-0 0, Bryant 5-15 0-0 14, Pearson 2-3 0-0 4. Totals 18-56 8-15 49.

INDIANA (7-1)

Williams 5-7 2-3 12, Mosquera-Perea 1-1 0-0 2, Blackmon Jr. 5-10 4-4 18, Johnson 3-6 3-4 10, Ferrell 5-9 7-7 18, Zeisloft 3-5 0-0 9, Hoetzel 1-3 2-2 4, Burton 0-0 0-0 0, Robinson 3-5 1-1 7, Ritchie 0-0 0-0 0, Holt 2-3 4-4 8, Hartman 3-3 0-0 7, Priller 0-2 0-0 0, April 0-0 0-0 0. Totals 31-54 23-25 95.

Halftime—Indiana 43-17. 3-Point Goals—Savannah St. 5-22 (Bryant 4-12, Jenkins 1-4, Pinkett 0-1, Hall 0-1, Fenner 0-1, Norman 0-1, Francis 0-2), Indiana 10-21 (Blackmon Jr. 4-7, Zeisloft 3-5, Hartman 1-1, Johnson 1-2, Ferrell 1-3, Priller 0-1, Hoetzel 0-1, Robinson 0-1). Fouled Out—None. Rebounds—Savannah St. 24 (Muhammad 6), Indiana 42 (Johnson 7). Assists—Savannah St. 11 (Hall 6), Indiana 21 (Ferrell 7). Total Fouls—Savannah St. 20, Indiana 16. A—17,472.

IU vs. Louisville in New York, 9 p.m. Tuesday
